chapter.title: Control flow expressions
chapter.para: JSONiq supports control flow expressions such as if-then-else, switch and typeswitch.

section.title: Conditional expressions
section.para: A conditional expressions allows you to pick one or another value depending on a boolean value.
The behavior of the expression inside the if is similar to that of logical operations, meaning that non-boolean get converted to a boolean.

formalpara.title: Result (run with Zorba):
formalpara.para: An error was raised: "[JSONXQType object]": invalid argument type for function fn:boolean()

section.title: Switch expressions
section.para: A switch expression evaluates the expression inside the switch. If it is an atomic, it compares it in turn to the provided atomic values (with the semantics of the eq operator) and returns the value associated with the first matching case clause.

example.title: A switch expression
example.programlisting: switch ("foo") case "bar" return "foo" case "foo" return "bar" default return "none"
example.para: If it is not an atomic, an error is raised.
example.programlisting: switch ({ "foo" : "bar" }) case "bar" return "foo" case "foo" return "bar" default return "none"

formalpara.title: Result (run with Zorba):
formalpara.para: An error was raised: invalid expression: syntax error, unexpected end of file, the query body should not be empty

section.para: If no value matches, the default is used.

example.title: A switch expression
example.programlisting: switch ("no-match") case "bar" return "foo" case "foo" return "bar" default return "none"

section.para: The case clauses support composability of expressions as well.

example.title: A switch expression
example.programlisting: switch (2) case 1 + 1 return "foo" case 2 + 2 return "bar" default return "none"

example.title: A switch expression
example.programlisting: switch (true) case 1 + 1 eq 2 return "1 + 1 is 2" case 2 + 2 eq 5 return "2 + 2 is 5" default return "none of the above is true"
